Negotiating trade agreements (D) and initiating international arbitration (E) provide non-military avenues for resolving tensions. Surveillance (I) and increasing cyber capacities (J) are important for maintaining situational awareness and readiness. However, options involving direct military action, like supplying weapons (N) or increasing military capacities (K), are less favorable as they escalate tensions. Cutting diplomatic relationships (L) and imposing trade restrictions (M) can exacerbate the situation. Attacking (O, P) or full-scale invasion (Q, R, S) are extreme measures that would lead to significant conflict and are therefore ranked as the least reasonable options.
